urn:contentItem:5MJ5-RGP1-DYG0-94K5-00000-00FED:International markets roundup2017-01-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:49:32ZLexisNexisFINANCIAL NEWSFED:International markets roundupSYDNEY Jan 3

  NEW YORK - US markets were closed for trading due to a public holiday on Monday.
   US stocks slumped on the last trading day of 2016, led down by Apple and other big tech stocks, but major indexes still posted solid gains for the year.


   In subdued holiday trading on Friday, the S&P 500 declined for a third consecutive session.
   But the benchmark index still tallied an annual gain of 9.5 per cent. The Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed 13.4 per cent for 2016, even as it recorded its first weekly decline since the US election on November 8.
   Stocks stalled this week after surging in the wake of Donald Trump's presidential election. Investors have bet Trump will cut taxes and regulations, and introduce fresh economic stimulus.
   "It's been such a significant run-up that there's been a pause," said Bucky Hellwig, senior vice president at BB&T Wealth Management in Birmingham, Alabama.
   "We are to the point now where there's uncertainty with regard to what policies are implemented, when are they implemented and how are they going to affect the economy as a whole and industries specifically."
   The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 57.18 points, or 0.29 per cent, to 19,762.6, the S&P 500 lost 10.43 points, or 0.46 per cent, to 2,238.83 and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 48.97 points, or 0.9 per cent, to 5,383.12.
   LONDON - Major European equity indexes climbed to new highs in thin trading on Monday, with strong manufacturing reports from the region boosting sentiment on the first trading day of 2017.
   Italy's FTSE MIB index was up 1.7 per cent at its close, hitting its highest level since January 2016. Germany's DAX rose 1 per cent after reaching to its highest in nearly 17 months, while France's CAC gained 0.4 per cent following a 13-month peak earlier in the day.
   The euro zone's blue-chip Euro STOXX 50 index was up 0.6 per cent, the highest level since December 2015, with a brighter macroeconomic picture helping the broader market.
   The pan-European STOXX 600 rose 0.5 per cent and held at one-year highs.
   British and Swiss markets were closed.
   IHS Markit's 2016 manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index for the euro zone registered 54.9 in December, its highest since April 2011. That was well above both the 50 mark which separates growth from contraction, and above November's 53.7.
   German manufacturing growth reached its highest in almost three years, driven by rising demand from Asia and the United States. French manufacturing hit a 5-1/2 year high, and Italian manufacturing activity grew at its fastest rate since June.
   "It's nice to see some good economic numbers on the first trading day of the ... year. It has improved sentiment and could help the market to set new highs in the coming months," said Koen De Leus, chief economist at BNP Paribas Fortis.
   "However, the road ahead looks bumpy because of several political risks in Europe. Overall, I am positive on European stocks this year as valuations are quite attractive compared to the United States and company margins are slowly improving, helped as well by the cheap euro."
   Trading was thin, with volumes at 35 per cent for the CAC index and 41.8 per cent for the euro STOXX 50 of their 90-day daily averages.
   Britain's blue-chip FTSE 100 index closed 2016 at a record high on Friday after clocking a yearly gain of 14.4 per cent, the best performer among major European stock indexes, with a sharp decline in sterling after the vote to leave the EU helping exporters and stronger metals prices boosting miners.
   All of Asia's major markets were also closed on Monday for the New Year holiday.

urn:contentItem:5SN5-GWK1-F06X-W4RY-00000-00Fed may change stress test grading; Amex wins2018-06-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:49:32ZLexisNexisFed may change stress test grading; Amex winsGeorge Yacik

Receiving Wide Coverage ...

Amex prevails: By a 5-4 vote, the Supreme Court upheld American Express' policy of preventing retailers from offering consumers incentives to pay with cheaper cards, "a major victory for the company that puts its business model on solid legal ground." The decision "handed a loss to a group of more than a dozen states and the Justice Department, which brought an antitrust challenge" against the credit card company, the Wall Street Journal says.

"The ruling removes a major threat to AmEx after nearly a decade of litigation," the paper adds. "The ruling is also a setback for the merchants' broader ambitions to lower credit card swipe-fees."Wall Street Journal,Financial Times,New York Times,American Banker

While the decision at first glance appears to be a victory for Amex over Visa and Mastercard, it could help all three networks "by supporting theirrelatively high feesin the U.S." and "further entrench all three in the U.S. payments market," the Heard on the Street column says. "The losers will be upstarts trying to create new payment systems that don't use the credit card networks."

Former Amex CEO Kenneth Chenault and his board get kudos from the Journal "for seeing the case through to victory." But it had nothing but scorn for the Justice Department's antitrust division, which received a "sharp rebuke" and an "embarrassing lesson" from the court forbringing a "dubious" antitrust caseagainst the company.

The decision could have wider implications, especially in the tech industry, the Washington Post observes. "Similar to Amex, companies such as Amazon, Facebook and Google operate in two-sided markets: All serve average Internet users on the one hand, while doing business with third-party companies, including independent retailers and advertisers. The Court's ruling couldshield tech platforms from litigationif plaintiffs cannot prove that both sides of a two-sided market are being harmed by the platform's practices."

But Big Tech could face antitrust concerns on other fronts, namely the ban by Google, Facebook, Amazon and Microsoft on cryptocurrency ads, which "threaten the fledgling industry's existence," Mark Epstein, an antitrust attorney, writes in a Journal op-ed. All four companies offer online or peer-to-peer payment services, which compete against digital exchanges such as Coinbase and Binance. "In effect, four of the eight largest companies in the world control an online-advertising oligopoly and aredenying competitors accessto these services," Epstein says.

Big money: Speaking of cryptocurrency, Andreessen Horowitz, the Silicon Valley venture capital firm, said it has raised $300 million to back blockchain and cryptocurrency-related ideas, including investing in digital currencies directly. The firm named Katie Haun, a former DOJ prosecutor, to help manage the fund, becoming the firm's first female general partner. She said she would help the company "foster responsible innovation and strike the right balance between innovation and regulation."Wall Street Journal,Financial Times,New York Times

Wall Street Journal

Failure is not an option: The Federal Reserve is moving toward getting rid of pass-or-fail grades on bank stress tests and replacing them with a public capital ratio that the bank must meet. The new grading system, which may go into effect as soon as next year, "reflects the Fed's uneasiness with surprising bankers and financial markets with bad news" and "demonstrates how Fed officials have grownmore comfortable with big banks' risk-managementchops."

David takes on Goliath: "A handful of upstart advisers are challenging investment banks on turf once thought impenetrable: the $7 billion-a-year business of handling complex stock-related transactions," the paper reports. "Without underwriting or trading arms, these advisers say they can giveunbiased judgmentand help clients wrangle a horde of hungry bankers. Their pitch is resonating, especially in Silicon Valley, where finance departments tend to be less robust and more suspicious of Wall Street."

Financial Times

Welcome aboard: HSBC has hired Ewen Stevenson away from Royal Bank of Scotland to be its chief financial officer, the "first significant management appointmentunder the bank's new leadership team." He will succeed Iain Mackay, who is retiring after eight years on the job. The paper says HSBC paid up to £10.6 million to buy out Stevenson's unvested bonuses at RBS.

Quotable

"The Supreme Court's decision is a major victory for consumers and for American Express. It will help topromote competition and innovationin the payments industry.

urn:contentItem:60VK-40V1-F07F-84BD-00000-00FED møde: Powell lufter risiko for finansiel stabilitet, presser aktier2020-09-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:49:32ZLexisNexisNEWSFED møde: Powell lufter risiko for finansiel stabilitet, presser aktierMorten W. Langer

Fra Zerohedge: Lower (rates) for longer (at least 2024) but inflation, growth, and rate projections are all inconsistent . As Peter Boockvar at Bleakley Advisory Group points out the committee cut its 2021 GDP forecast to 4% from 5%, while at the same time... Fra Zerohedge: Lower (rates) for longer...

Fra Zerohedge: Lower (rates) for longer (at least 2024) but inflation, growth, and rate projections are all inconsistent . As Peter Boockvar at Bleakley Advisory Group points out the committee cut its 2021 GDP forecast to 4% from 5%, while at the same time...

Fra Zerohedge: Lower (rates) for longer (at least 2024) but inflation, growth, and rate projections are all inconsistent . As Peter Boockvar at Bleakley Advisory Group points out the committee cut its 2021 GDP forecast to 4% from 5%, while at the same time lowering forecasts for the unemployment rate to 5.5% from 6.5% and raising core PCE estimates to 1.7% from 1.5%. “No color on the inconsistency,” says Boockvar. “They somehow think that the longer-run fed funds rate should be 2.5% but they have no intentions on trying to get there for the next 3 years, even if we get a vaccine, which we know is the main reason why we’re in the circumstances we are in.” Stocks didn’t care – they just rallied (while everything else largely shrugged) and everything was looking good… until Powell was asked about financial stability (in other words – bubbles): “Monetary policy should not be the first line of defense,” Powell says, noting regulatory tools should be the first line. “We always leave open the idea that we will not ignore those kinds of risks. ” Powell was pressed further as to whether such bubble concerns could prompt a rate hike . Powell said that the majority of the FOMC would need to have concluded that the monetary stance was fostering financial instability.. but the market did not like that and stocks were slammed lower… Did the market just warn Powell not to “meddle with the primary forces of nature…money!”… Overall, from the FOMC statement drop, the dollar is modestly higher and big tech stocks worst… Nasdaq has tumbled to its lowest relative to Small Caps in almost a month… Source: Bloomberg Of course, we couldn’t continue without mentioning SNOW – which exploded out of its IPO, before sliding back from exuberant opening levels… Treasury yields moved marginally higher (10Y +1bps)… Source: Bloomberg But short-term markets remain convinced there will be no rate hike until mid-2024… Source: Bloomberg FX markets were largely clueless with the dollar whipping around all over the place… Source: Bloomberg Bitcoin surged back above $11,000… Source: Bloomberg WTI topped $40 after a surprise crude draw… Gold was unchanged on the day… Finally, this won’t end well… Source: Bloomberg And as Bloomberg notes, this year’s gap between the S&P 500 Index’s best- and worst-performing industry groups is unusually wide. Technology stocks climbed 27% to rank first among the S&P 500’s 11 sectors as of Tuesday, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. Energy was last with a 47% loss. The differential of 74 percentage points between them was the widest through Sept. 15 for any two sectors since 2000. Back then, utility stocks led the way and raw-material producers trailed as a bear market got underway. Source: Bloomberg

urn:contentItem:5W8F-T2G1-JCMN-Y2NV-00000-00Fed Reassures Economy, Trade Rhetoric Softens, Stocks to Consider in the Aftermath2019-06-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:49:32ZLexisNexisFed Reassures Economy, Trade Rhetoric Softens, Stocks to Consider in the AftermathChristopher Vargas

Jun 04, 2019( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) U.S. stocks experienced a surge today in the aftermath of Fed chairman Jerome Powell stating the central bank was willing to ease monetary policy if needed to stabilize the economy. The announcement came amidst the ongoing trade war between the U.S and some of its biggest sources of imports. During a press conference held in Chicago, Powell assured the public that the Fed is aware and monitoring current economic developments and will act accordingly to sustain the near-record economic expansion.[1]The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S...00, and the Nasdaq all rebounded today, each closing up over 2%; the Dow added 511 points. These index increases come as a sigh of relief after a lackluster May for the market as many stocks felt the ramifications of the heated trade rhetoric.The positive news from the central bank was accompanied by China easing the tensions of the trade war.

A spokesperson for China's Ministry of Commerce released a statement that the trade dispute should be handled with 'dialogue and consultation.'[2] They followed up the statement by pointing out that these talks would need to be conducted with 'respect, equality, and mutual benefit.'The report comes after both sides recently escalated the dispute through threats of cutting off needed resources. The tariffs President Trump threatened to issue on some Mexican goods were followed by Mexican Foreign Minister Marcelo Ebrard stating that he believed the two countries could find common ground.[3] The positive news lead to a surge in stocks that previously fell victim to the trade war rhetoric such as General MotorsGM[4] and Ford F[5]. Major tech companies also felt the impact of the news and here are the ones to be most attentive to.AppleOn Monday, AppleAAPL[6] announced upcoming product launch plans at its Worldwide Developer Conference. The company showcased new features it developed for iPhones, as well as its newest Mac Pro, which it presented as its most powerful computer to date. The highlight of the conference was the company's new tool, 'sign in with Apple.' It provides developers the option to add to apps that would allow users to log in without the creation of a username and password. According to Apple, this option doesn't gather any personal information from the user. This feature distinguishes Apple from companies like Facebook[7], who are under scrutiny because of the lack of privacy it gives users. Shares of AAPL have gained 9.86% year-to-date, and the stock currently sits at a #3 (Hold) on the Zacks Rank.FacebookFacebook FB[8] has been under investigation for its privacy policies because of the data it collects from its users. Shares of the company took a hit Monday as antitrust regulation fears impacted the market; government threats to investigate big tech companies for violations of antitrust laws have made investors wary of delving into big tech stocks. Despite possibly facing regulatory sanctions from the government, analysts don't believe it will affect the company's fundamentals.[9] Many analysts also don't believe that the regulators will come down as hard as many perceive. Breaking up these tech conglomerates is unlikely[10] as these investigations are in their early stages. This analyst sentiment as well as some positive estimate revision and Facebook's Estimated Long-Term EPS Growth Rate of +20.20% give the social media giant a #2 (Buy) on the Zacks Rank. The company is also projected to see year-over-year earnings growth of +9.20% for the current fiscal quarter.Today's Best Stocks from ZacksWould you like to see the updated picks from our best market-beating strategies? From 2017 through 2018, while the S...00 gained +15.8%, five of our screens returned +38.0%, +61.3%, +61.6%, +68.1%, and +98.3%.This outperformance has not just been a recent phenomenon. From 2000 - 2018, while the S...veraged +4.8% per year, our top strategies averaged up to +56.2% per year.See their latest picks free >>[11] Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? urn:contentItem:5DCP-XPC1-F0HW-505K-00000-00Fed Releases Beige Book; FED: Districts Generally Reporting Modest To Moderate Economic Growth; 10-Year Yield Hits 17-Month Low; Second Texas2014-10-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:49:32ZLexisNexisFed Releases Beige Book; FED: Districts Generally Reporting Modest To Moderate Economic Growth; 10-Year Yield Hits 17-Month Low; Second Texas

MELISSA FRANCIS, MONEY HOST: All three major averages down about 2.5 percent on the day. You could see there, the S&P, the biggest loser on a percentage basis.

Investors rushing to the safety of bonds, the 10-year treasury yield now at about 2 percent, just higher than that. It is the lowest level that we have seen since May of last year.

Now we are going to hear from the Fed. We are seconds away from the latest Beige Book report on the economy. We have an all-star panel standing by to react. There we go.

Let's go to Peter Barnes with the breaking news. Peter?

PETER BARNES, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Well, hi, Melissa, the 12 Federal Reserve banks reported modest to moderate economic growth in this latest survey of economic conditions. This is the Beige Book that the Fed will use at its next policy meeting at the end of this month when it is expected to end its latest round of quantitative easing.

I looked through the report to find -- check on some of the issues that are concerning investors right know exports, for example, to Europe and oil supplies and prices. And I did find this reference from the Cleveland Federal Reserve Bank. It said, "That manufacturing firms there seeing lower production attributed it to seasonal factors or declining exports."

On excess supplies of crude oil, the Beige Book does report on that and uses the term, "excess supplies" reporting on its context in the period up to October 6th. It says, "Oil exploration activity increased in the Minneapolis, Kansas City, and Dallas Districts." and of course the Minneapolis District does include those big shale oil reserves in North Dakota.

But, again, this information was all collected before October 6th. We've had a lot happened since then. The Dow down, 1,000 points since October 6th unclear how these latest developments in the markets will affect Fed policy making at the end of this month.

Melissa?

FRANCIS: All right, Peter Barnes reporting in disguise there. Thank you so much. Let's get to the market reaction right now.

It has been a rough run today. The Dow diving more than 400 points, so now we're down 420. When we came on the air a few seconds ago we were down 400. We're all over the map today. It is the steepest drop in more than three years. One of the big reasons, Ebola. Let's get you up to speed on the very latest on that one that caused the free fall this morning.

A second person contracted Ebola in the U.S. The patient has not yet been identified but it has been confirmed that the health care worker did travel by air before experiencing any symptoms of the deadly disease, the beginning of this week that was. The president is set to meet with cabinet leaders in just over an hour from now. They're going to discuss the government's response to this growing crisis.

Let's bring in today's panel. We have Fox Business's Charlie Gasparino, the Wall Street Journal's James Freeman is with us and co-founder of WhoWeUse, Spencer Ante is here as well.

Charlie?

CHARLIE GASPARINO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK: I would say part of the drop that's going down and every time we take eye an off the markets, it goes down.

FRANCIS: Right, it.

GASPARINO: And what do we have now, right?

FRANCIS: It's amazing. 420.

GASPARINO: To the point.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

GASPARINO: . I think some of the drop right now is attributed, I think, to David Asman's report earlier that Richard Fisher.

FRANCIS: Yes.

GASPARINO: . now he's a hawk but David reported exclusively that Fisher has ruled out QE. Look at it this way.

FRANCIS: Way too premature is what he said.

GASPARINO: . is that he's way too -- yes, way too -- so it means it's not going to happen anytime soon. Here is what the market loves. The market loves printing money. It knows that the global economy isn't doing so well. There's lots of fears out there. This is not a good environment to be owning stocks if the Fed is not going to ease.

FRANCIS: I think David Asman's going to be out later with more on that report. I just want to give you a couple of the headlines that are coming from David Asman's conversation with Fisher saying that the market correction doesn't mean the economy is in trouble. What do you think about that one, James Freeman?

JAMES FREEMAN, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL AND WHOWEUSE CO-FOUNDER: Well, I think that this is an issue we've talked about recently where he's trying to, I think, partly get out in front of his Fed colleagues. He knows a lot of them do not have market experience. And as academics, they can get rattled a bit.

FRANCIS: That's terrifying.

FREEMAN: . they can get rattled a bit sort of like Geithner was during the crisis where people on the street would whisper to him scary stuff without the experience to know he would kind of overreact. And I think that's what Fisher may be concerned about with some of his Fed colleagues.

GASPARINO: Do you think the economy is getting better? I mean.

FREEMAN: Slowly, yes, I do. And I think his point -- what Fisher, I think he's right on the money.

FRANCIS: You know, wait, wait, wait, I mean, let me stop you right there because you look at the data that's coming out of Germany, you look at the data that's coming out of China...

GASPARINO: Not good.

FRANCIS: . it seems like globally, I don't know, it feels like something has happened, something has shifted and we aren't all of a sudden getting better the way they were. You don't agree with that?

FREEMAN: I agree. Europe is depressing. I think the U.S. economy is still plugging along.

SPENCER ANTE, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: I agree with that. I think China is slowing down and Europ is slowing down but the U.S. is the main bright spot in the global economy. And.

FRANCIS: But how can we keep this lower.

GASPARINO: It's not going to last.

FRANCIS: Right. How can we keep this going.

GASPARINO: I will say this.

FRANCIS: . if they're staggering.

GASPARINO: Let's bring this politically.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

GASPARINO: One thing that Hillary Clinton is -- what she's worried about, big time, is the fact that economies generally -- economic cycles generally run in seven years. And seven year for this economic cycle is coming to an end.

FREEMAN: Yeah, but this isn't a normal cycle. It's been such slow growth.

GASPARINO: That is -- I know, that's the counter argument.

FREEMAN: Normally, I mean, it's different from so many other good.

FRANCIS: OK.

FREEMAN: . recoveries. So I wouldn't expect them.

GASPARINO: But we do know. But you don't know.

FREEMAN: . to be similar in that way.

FRANCIS: I want to -- Let's talk specifically about this big move that we've seen today because it is staggering.

Charlie, there were a lot of folks talking earlier today about maybe a Hedge Fund liquidation.

GASPARINO: Yeah, I mean, listen, here's the thing. You had that Shire deal, the Shire -- there was that.

FREEMAN: AbbVie.

GASPARINO: . AbbVie, right. Now that deal, this is a little technical, but here's what happened. A lot of people -- a lot of arbs got in that deal, meaning professional traders who bet the deal would happen. So they would go along the stock that was being bought. In short, the stock that was being sold, that was the acquirer.

FRANCIS: OK.

GASPARINO: . and guess what happened? That deal didn't happen. So all those arbs got crushed and what they did was they sold stock and they went into bonds. That's why you saw the 10-year go down on basis points and on the yield on 10-year go down.

PETALLIDES: An idea like it's almost that there needs to be more of a cleanse, I don't know how many.

FRANCIS: Yeah. Total capitulation. Yeah.

PETALLIDES: Yeah. All right, Nicole, thank you so much.

Oil prices down, they are not out there crude dropping all the way to $80 a barrel before climbing back a little bit here. It is been Roscoe oil down 10 percent in the past month alone. You may be surprised whose really getting hurt by cheap oil.

Let's bring in trader Scott Shellady at the CME, James is here as well.

I mean, of course this is fantastic news for drivers. Everybody who's filled up lately is very excited about this. We wanted to point to the other side of the trade, because there's some interesting folks in the other side, the most obvious of which is certainly the Saudis.

Prince Alwaleed bin Talal is talking about the catastrophe in oil prices and the fact that he thinks the Saudi oil minister isn't serious enough and isn't worried enough about this decline.

Scott, what do you think?

SCOTT SHELLADY, CME GROUP: I think there's kind of a story underneath here that says they're trying to try that even the U.S. producers out of business. They want to see how low they could go and I think that our numbers are rounded $60 a barrel. They want to push it down there to start to really -- they want to give us some pain. So there is a little bit of a fight under here that we're not really seeing.

FRANCIS: OK.

SHELLADY: But I think that there could be something there about pushing it low to hurt us, not them.

FRANCIS: No, that's an interesting point of view and, James, we'll ask you about that because we were looking at Ali Al-Naimi there on the screen who is the Saudi oil minister next to Prince Alwaleed and, you know, that for shale, so there's been a huge shale revolution here in the U.S. but the breakeven price is said to be $80 to $85 on Brent.

Do you think it's possible that these guys are trying to drive the shale drillers here in the U.S. out of business?

FREEMAN: Well, you can come up with a lot of theories. Vladimir Putin thinks that.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

FREEMAN: . this is aimed at him. And I think -- I see a lot of upside here and not just people driving their cars, it's everyone who's using petroleum to create products, so do all kinds of commerce, the people who are hurt the most are not the U.S. frackers there. As we said, Putin's Russia, Venezuela, they all have budgets built on very high oil prices.

So basically what you're doing is you're squeezing the world's dictators.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

FREEMAN: . while you get U.S. consumers in business as a price cut.

FRANCIS: No, that's a great point. That's a great point. And, Scott, I mean, what do you think about that, because you look at the price decline there. You know, every dollar decline that we see in the price of oil translates to about $2 billion in losses for Putin and for Russia.

What do you think, Scott?

SHELLADY: And I think that, you know, I think that that could -- it could be a little bit self-centered on their behalf but at the end of the day, it's about the dollar and I think that oil still is a harbor chair for the economy and the economy is not doing well. I don't think these low oil prices are going to port over to better retail sales and a better economy. I think the reason why -- A lot of the reason why oil is going down is the consumer just doesn't have that money anymore and we've started to see some of these retail sales numbers like today coming in.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

SHELLADY: . a little weak and it's going to continue that way.

FRANCIS: OK.

SHELLADY: The worst is yet to come. The worst is yet to come.

FRANCIS: On that, you know, we're going to leave the segment, thank you so much Scott and James.

We are keeping a very close eye in the market. The Dow right now is down 302 points. What do you do with your money right now? The trader and the money manager's take. We've got that next.

You can never have too much "money", that is for sure.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: Stocks still in the red as the Dow suffers its steepest intraday decline in almost three years.

Here with some advice for your money is Alan Knuckman from Bulls-eye Options, we also have Dominic Tavella from Diversified Financial

Dominic, you want to be the voice of reason. Go ahead.

DOMINIC TAVELLA, DIVERSIFIED FINANCIAL FOUNDER AND PRESIDENT: Look, these headlines are scary for people and I'm not really talking about the guys sitting at his office or at home and going, "I'm going to rebalance my 401K Com, I broke -- let's be reasonable here. There are more people that die in this country from the flu, 25,000 people a year that have died so far. No one, no one's died from Ebola American in this country so far

The U.S. is growing. We're probably around 3 percent. China, India, growing about 4 percent or 7 percent.

FRANCIS: OK.

TAVELLA: . that's 65 percent of the world GDP.

FRANCIS: So, Alan, I mean that sounds very rational. Why then at the OPEC do we see just a washout?

ALAN KNUCKMAN, BULLS-EYE OPTION: I think people get a lot of information and have a difficulty processing it. The fundamentals haven't changed just like we stated. Right now, we've got record low interest rates plunging here the 10-year notes, bouncing off at 2 percent. We were worried about rates going up. That's not going to happen. Earning here is still fantastic, oil prices are going down. So all these things are positive fundamentals but the markets get overdone because of psychology, everybody was worried about a selloff.

FRANCIS: OK.

KNUCKMAN: . and now they've got something to worry about.

FRANCIS: Let me challenge you though, are you sure that the fundamentals haven't changed? I mean, you look at the data coming out of Germany, you look at the data coming out of China, there is a slowdown going on elsewhere around the world. How is it not going to be contagious here in the U.S. where we're seeing a bit of growth, but not much? Dominic?

TAVELLA: So let's focus on energy, right, which I think is a fantastic story. It's estimated that between $75 billion and $100 billion will come back to the consumer because of lower energy prices. That's equal to the Obama tax increase last year. So consumers are going to get that back in their pocket just in time for Christmas, that's going to help our economy.

FRANCIS: Alan, what do you think about that? I mean, is that enough or it is the reason why oils lower because everything is slowing down around the world and people aren't driving as much because they don't have money and they're not going to out shopping and they're not going out to do things. Go ahead.

KNUCKMAN: I think it's nothing but a benefit but I think that if you want to look at Europe slowing, that's going to make our markets more attractive in the long-run.

FRANCIS: OK.

KNUCKMAN: So from my standpoint, I'm looking at scaling back in here. I was surprised, I didn't think the market could go straight down for three weeks but, you know, I got knocked out following my plan but we can always get back in with a clear head and I think that's where we have to look at here.

FRANICS: Gentlemen, thanks to both of you.

No doubt this has been a tough day for the marketer. Our very own Liz Claman is here to give us a preview of what's coming up in the next and most important hour of trading.

Liz.

LIZ CLAMAN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: I love to tell you earlier, I said, "It looks better. It's down 280 points."

FRANCIS: Right.

CLAMAN: Listen, perspective at the moment.

FRANCIS: Take improvements.

CLAMAN: That's exactly what we're going to give you in this final hour in which we know anything can happen. We could see in an acceleration to the downside or we could see a fight back to at least getting closer to the green. So we're going to take you to every index trading floor that matters. We're talking to traders. We're talking of money experts as we look at the markets right now. It is pretty much a mess at the moment. We do have the S&P down 30 points, the Nasdaq down 53. It is truly just a lot of red on the screen but we wouldn't exactly call it a complete capitulation. You were addressing that too.

So we've got two experts here. One of them runs a fund, the Hennessey Funds which is actually over the past 10 years during which we know there's been so much going on returned an annual live 10 percent. So David Raney is important to hear from right now, he's a good investor. James Bianco of Bianoc Research, he's going to be talking specifically about the technical levels you need to worry about the most and are we seeing capitulation? He is the man to be answering that.

And at this point, when we have seen the 10-year yield fall below 2 percent earlier today, why not just buy Intel. Look at the Intel yield, 2.8 percent. First on Fox Business interview with the Dow component CEO Brian Krzanich, he is going to come right here on Fox, I'm going to ask him all of this global turmoil. They do 80 percent of their business outside the U.S. Is that going to affect the current quarter? That may mean a lot to all technology investments.

Plus, they have a brand new phone/tablet, a two in one that just rolled out with ASUS but it's got that Intel chip in it. Wait until you see this thing. It's called the PadFone, we're talking to Brian about all that and so much more at first on Fox Business. See you at the top of the hour.

FRANCIS: We look forward to it, Liz. Thank you so much.

CLAMAN: You got it.

Netflix prepares for earnings, but in these cell streaming device, it could be hurting its bottom-line.

At the end of the day, it is all about "money".

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: President Obama delaying his fundraising and campaign events today so that he can remain at the White House for a meeting with cabinet members on Ebola just moments ago.

White House Press Secretary John Earnest saying the president felt like he needed to be in the White House to fulfill his responsibilities. We're going to bring you any updates as we have them. That's a switch from the past by the way.

Netflix set to report a third-quarter earnings after the Belden stock came session lows after HBO announced it will launch a stand-alone streaming service for next year.

Our very own Jo Ling Kent is at the Nasdaq, James and Spencer back as well.

Jo, tell me about Netflix right now. What's it doing?

KENT: Well, it's down a little less than 1 percent. Now, like you said off the session lows, we're expecting an EPS of 93 cents of share, (inaudible) looking for a revenue of $1.41 billion. But there could be a silver lining here if HBO continues to be competitive to Netflix. Of all the people who are cutting quarters, maybe they'll migrate to Netflix as well.

FRANCIS: Yeah, interesting. Spencer, what do you think about Netflix after the bell and what do you think about the competition from HBO here?

ANTE: You know, honestly, I'm surprised that Netflix is not down more than 1 percent and change right now, you know, because HBO is saying they're going over the top is definitely the single biggest new competitor and threat they face when HBO releases that service in 2015.

So I think that people maybe underestimating the power of.

FRANCIS: OK.

ANTE: . this new service.

FRANCIS: James?

FREEMAN: Yeah, I think it suggests maybe questions about whether HBO can execute. As far as Netflix, obviously, they're priced for a lot of growth in the future. They have to pay a lot for programming, whether they can keep that edge in terms of user friendly experience.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

FREEMAN: Big question.

FRANCIS: OK. Thanks to all three of you. Stay tuned at Fox Business, we're going to have live coverage of Netflix earnings on "After the Bell" coming straight after this. That is all we have for now. I hope that you are somehow making money today. The market is down 279. It was much worse earlier. Stay tuned.

Liz Claman in "Countdown" starts right now.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5J41-H501-DY0W-42GF-00000-00Fed Releases Beige Book; FED: Districts Generally Reporting Modest To Moderate Economic Growth; 10-Year Yield Hits 17-Month Low; Second Texas2014-10-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:49:32ZLexisNexisFed Releases Beige Book; FED: Districts Generally Reporting Modest To Moderate Economic Growth; 10-Year Yield Hits 17-Month Low; Second TexasLanhamFULL TEXT

MELISSA FRANCIS, MONEY HOST: All three major averages down about 2.5 percent on the day. You could see there, the S&P, the biggest loser on a percentage basis.

Investors rushing to the safety of bonds, the 10-year treasury yield now at about 2 percent, just higher than that. It is the lowest level that we have seen since May of last year.

Now we are going to hear from the Fed. We are seconds away from the latest Beige Book report on the economy. We have an all-star panel standing by to react. There we go.

Let's go to Peter Barnes with the breaking news. Peter?

PETER BARNES, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Well, hi, Melissa, the 12 Federal Reserve banks reported modest to moderate economic growth in this latest survey of economic conditions. This is the Beige Book that the Fed will use at its next policy meeting at the end of this month when it is expected to end its latest round of quantitative easing.

I looked through the report to find -- check on some of the issues that are concerning investors right know exports, for example, to Europe and oil supplies and prices. And I did find this reference from the Cleveland Federal Reserve Bank. It said, "That manufacturing firms there seeing lower production attributed it to seasonal factors or declining exports."

On excess supplies of crude oil, the Beige Book does report on that and uses the term, "excess supplies" reporting on its context in the period up to October 6th. It says, "Oil exploration activity increased in the Minneapolis, Kansas City, and Dallas Districts." and of course the Minneapolis District does include those big shale oil reserves in North Dakota.

But, again, this information was all collected before October 6th. We've had a lot happened since then. The Dow down, 1,000 points since October 6th unclear how these latest developments in the markets will affect Fed policy making at the end of this month.

Melissa?

FRANCIS: All right, Peter Barnes reporting in disguise there. Thank you so much. Let's get to the market reaction right now.

It has been a rough run today. The Dow diving more than 400 points, so now we're down 420. When we came on the air a few seconds ago we were down 400. We're all over the map today. It is the steepest drop in more than three years. One of the big reasons, Ebola. Let's get you up to speed on the very latest on that one that caused the free fall this morning.

A second person contracted Ebola in the U.S. The patient has not yet been identified but it has been confirmed that the health care worker did travel by air before experiencing any symptoms of the deadly disease, the beginning of this week that was. The president is set to meet with cabinet leaders in just over an hour from now. They're going to discuss the government's response to this growing crisis.

Let's bring in today's panel. We have Fox Business's Charlie Gasparino, the Wall Street Journal's James Freeman is with us and co-founder of WhoWeUse, Spencer Ante is here as well.

Charlie?

CHARLIE GASPARINO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK: I would say part of the drop that's going down and every time we take eye an off the markets, it goes down.

FRANCIS: Right, it.

GASPARINO: And what do we have now, right?

FRANCIS: It's amazing. 420.

GASPARINO: To the point.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

GASPARINO: . I think some of the drop right now is attributed, I think, to David Asman's report earlier that Richard Fisher.

FRANCIS: Yes.

GASPARINO: . now he's a hawk but David reported exclusively that Fisher has ruled out QE. Look at it this way.

FRANCIS: Way too premature is what he said.

GASPARINO: . is that he's way too -- yes, way too -- so it means it's not going to happen anytime soon. Here is what the market loves. The market loves printing money. It knows that the global economy isn't doing so well. There's lots of fears out there. This is not a good environment to be owning stocks if the Fed is not going to ease.

FRANCIS: I think David Asman's going to be out later with more on that report. I just want to give you a couple of the headlines that are coming from David Asman's conversation with Fisher saying that the market correction doesn't mean the economy is in trouble. What do you think about that one, James Freeman?

JAMES FREEMAN, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL AND WHOWEUSE CO-FOUNDER: Well, I think that this is an issue we've talked about recently where he's trying to, I think, partly get out in front of his Fed colleagues. He knows a lot of them do not have market experience. And as academics, they can get rattled a bit.

FRANCIS: That's terrifying.

FREEMAN: . they can get rattled a bit sort of like Geithner was during the crisis where people on the street would whisper to him scary stuff without the experience to know he would kind of overreact. And I think that's what Fisher may be concerned about with some of his Fed colleagues.

GASPARINO: Do you think the economy is getting better? I mean.

FREEMAN: Slowly, yes, I do. And I think his point -- what Fisher, I think he's right on the money.

FRANCIS: You know, wait, wait, wait, I mean, let me stop you right there because you look at the data that's coming out of Germany, you look at the data that's coming out of China...

GASPARINO: Not good.

FRANCIS: . it seems like globally, I don't know, it feels like something has happened, something has shifted and we aren't all of a sudden getting better the way they were. You don't agree with that?

FREEMAN: I agree. Europe is depressing. I think the U.S. economy is still plugging along.

SPENCER ANTE, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: I agree with that. I think China is slowing down and Europ is slowing down but the U.S. is the main bright spot in the global economy. And.

FRANCIS: But how can we keep this lower.

GASPARINO: It's not going to last.

FRANCIS: Right. How can we keep this going.

GASPARINO: I will say this.

FRANCIS: . if they're staggering.

GASPARINO: Let's bring this politically.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

GASPARINO: One thing that Hillary Clinton is -- what she's worried about, big time, is the fact that economies generally -- economic cycles generally run in seven years. And seven year for this economic cycle is coming to an end.

FREEMAN: Yeah, but this isn't a normal cycle. It's been such slow growth.

GASPARINO: That is -- I know, that's the counter argument.

FREEMAN: Normally, I mean, it's different from so many other good.

FRANCIS: OK.

FREEMAN: . recoveries. So I wouldn't expect them.

GASPARINO: But we do know. But you don't know.

FREEMAN: . to be similar in that way.

FRANCIS: I want to -- Let's talk specifically about this big move that we've seen today because it is staggering.

Charlie, there were a lot of folks talking earlier today about maybe a Hedge Fund liquidation.

GASPARINO: Yeah, I mean, listen, here's the thing. You had that Shire deal, the Shire -- there was that.

FREEMAN: AbbVie.

GASPARINO: . AbbVie, right. Now that deal, this is a little technical, but here's what happened. A lot of people -- a lot of arbs got in that deal, meaning professional traders who bet the deal would happen. So they would go along the stock that was being bought. In short, the stock that was being sold, that was the acquirer.

FRANCIS: OK.

GASPARINO: . and guess what happened? That deal didn't happen. So all those arbs got crushed and what they did was they sold stock and they went into bonds. That's why you saw the 10-year go down on basis points and on the yield on 10-year go down.

My bigger point is this, deals like this generally screw up when the economy and the markets are insane.

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: Go ahead. Yeah, go ahead. Go ahead.

ANTE: And so obviously the bad news is outweighing good news in the market right now. But one bit of good news is that oil and gas prices are falling.

FRANCIS: No, no, that's not good news. That's not good news.

ANTE: No, that is good news. Let's not over think this.

FRANCIS: No, it's not.

ANTE: Let me finish my point.

FRANCIS: OK.

ANTE: Seventy percent of consumers spending in the U.S. economy -- of GDP comes your consumer spending. When oil prices and gas prices go down, it puts more people in money's pockets and they use.

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: That's a good side of it. The bad side of it is the reason why it's happening.

GASPARINO: Right.

FRANCIS: . it's because there is a global slowdown going down.

GASPARINO: Right.

FRANCIS: Look at what's happening.

ANTE: There's a global increase in supply of oil because of better technology.

GASPARINO: There's never any good -- there's never any

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: All of a sudden, out of nowhere? No. There's a shrinking of demand in China, in Europe and that's why.

ANTE: Supply is the big factor here.

GASPARINO: Let me ask you a question. Why is it then that every time we get a lousy print, GDP print, from overseas, price of oil goes down? I mean, it's totally.

FRANCIS: That's the precall that we've seen.

GASPARINO: Yes?

FREEMAN: But the result is a good one. Things get cheaper for all kinds of consumers.

FRANCIS: The result is a good one, but the question is which has the bigger impact? And I don't know.

(CROSSTALK)

ANTE: . but all these things that's horrible for the economy.

FRANCIS: Absolutely.

ANTE: Oil prices are going down. Let's not over think it. It's one of the only bright spots we have right now.

GASPARINO: But inflation goes down when your economy slows. You know that.

ANTE: We're not talking about inflation.

GASPARINO: I'm just saying.

ANTE: There's deflation.

FRANCIS: Let's get back to today's market right here. So what are you hearing from folks about this particular selloff right now down 424.

GASPARINO: A lot of.

FRANCIS: . does it continue? Is this the bottom? Is this the beginning?

GASPARINO: Who knows? I mean, yes, I think it continues until the Fed gives us some clarity on rates. whether they do a QE, whether Richard Fisher is obviously overruled. I would say this. When I talk to money managers that deal with high net worth people.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

GASPARINO: . but they're getting a lot of calls from their rich clients, they're asking about deflation. There is an issue, there's a little spook on deflation out in the market right now.

FRANCIS: What do you think about the 10-year? What's the 10-year telling you?

FREEMAN: Well, obviously there's a lot of fear and we've talked about fundamentals.

FRANCIS: Here it is right here.

FREEMAN: . you talk about Germany, you talk about Europe, not seeming to be sliding back into recession. U.S. consumer spending also is not good. But I think Ebola is also part of the fear factor today.

FRANCIS: Without question.

FREEMAN: Why shouldn't it be?

ANTE: I talked to a broker at JPMorgan, (Piven Kline) yesterday and they're actually advising their clients to buy into these dips. So that's just one major bank advising their wealthiest clients that, you know, that don't panic, you know, and that this is an opportunity over the long-term.

FRANCIS: Do you think it's an opportunity?

FREEMAN: I would discount the Ebola threat. I mean, definitely this is.

FRANCIS: You would or would not?

FREEMAN: I would. This is an economic catastrophe in those countries in Africa where tons of.

GASPARINO: Yeah, but here's why.

FRANCI: I think they're very easy to overreact to this.

GASPARINO: I suppose people, at least in a short-term for a quarter, stopped going to movie theaters, stopped flying.

FRANCIS: Right.

GASPARINO: I mean, there's going to be a sizable economic impact because of this. I'm not saying it's real. I'm not saying this is.

FRANCIS: I don't know. I don't know.

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: Are we away from that because they are talking about this, so now this second person that's contracted in the United States flew on Monday, they're talking about the 132 people that were on the plane with this person when they flew on Monday, tracking them down, who have they have been in contact with. She is now sick. I mean, it's.

GASPARINO: Melissa, a friend of mine went by the Dallas hub of Newark yesterday and it was empty. OK. I'm just telling you whether it's real, not real, whether we're overblown.

FRANCIS: OK.

GASPARINO: . it's having an impact.

FRANCIS: Really briefly though, I want to point out there is some green on the board. Shares of Time Warner climbing after CEO Jeff Bewkes announcing the company will more than double its earnings over the next several years. I mean, this is one of the stocks that's in the positive zone.

GASPARINO: Right.

FRANCIS: . that's been getting some attention today. I don't want to totally ignore it.

GASPARINO: Right.

KNUCKMAN: . and now they've got something to worry about.

FRANCIS: Let me challenge you though, are you sure that the fundamentals haven't changed? I mean, you look at the data coming out of Germany, you look at the data coming out of China, there is a slowdown going on elsewhere around the world. How is it not going to be contagious here in the U.S. where we're seeing a bit of growth, but not much? Dominic?

TAVELLA: So let's focus on energy, right, which I think is a fantastic story. It's estimated that between $75 billion and $100 billion will come back to the consumer because of lower energy prices. That's equal to the Obama tax increase last year. So consumers are going to get that back in their pocket just in time for Christmas, that's going to help our economy.

FRANCIS: Alan, what do you think about that? I mean, is that enough or it is the reason why oils lower because everything is slowing down around the world and people aren't driving as much because they don't have money and they're not going to out shopping and they're not going out to do things. Go ahead.

KNUCKMAN: I think it's nothing but a benefit but I think that if you want to look at Europe slowing, that's going to make our markets more attractive in the long-run.

FRANCIS: OK.

KNUCKMAN: So from my standpoint, I'm looking at scaling back in here. I was surprised, I didn't think the market could go straight down for three weeks but, you know, I got knocked out following my plan but we can always get back in with a clear head and I think that's where we have to look at here.

FRANICS: Gentlemen, thanks to both of you.

No doubt this has been a tough day for the marketer. Our very own Liz Claman is here to give us a preview of what's coming up in the next and most important hour of trading.

Liz.

LIZ CLAMAN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: I love to tell you earlier, I said, "It looks better. It's down 280 points."

FRANCIS: Right.

CLAMAN: Listen, perspective at the moment.

FRANCIS: Take improvements.

CLAMAN: That's exactly what we're going to give you in this final hour in which we know anything can happen. We could see in an acceleration to the downside or we could see a fight back to at least getting closer to the green. So we're going to take you to every index trading floor that matters. We're talking to traders. We're talking of money experts as we look at the markets right now. It is pretty much a mess at the moment. We do have the S&P down 30 points, the Nasdaq down 53. It is truly just a lot of red on the screen but we wouldn't exactly call it a complete capitulation. You were addressing that too.

So we've got two experts here. One of them runs a fund, the Hennessey Funds which is actually over the past 10 years during which we know there's been so much going on returned an annual live 10 percent. So David Raney is important to hear from right now, he's a good investor. James Bianco of Bianoc Research, he's going to be talking specifically about the technical levels you need to worry about the most and are we seeing capitulation? He is the man to be answering that.

And at this point, when we have seen the 10-year yield fall below 2 percent earlier today, why not just buy Intel. Look at the Intel yield, 2.8 percent. First on Fox Business interview with the Dow component CEO Brian Krzanich, he is going to come right here on Fox, I'm going to ask him all of this global turmoil. They do 80 percent of their business outside the U.S. Is that going to affect the current quarter? That may mean a lot to all technology investments.

Plus, they have a brand new phone/tablet, a two in one that just rolled out with ASUS but it's got that Intel chip in it. Wait until you see this thing. It's called the PadFone, we're talking to Brian about all that and so much more at first on Fox Business. See you at the top of the hour.

FRANCIS: We look forward to it, Liz. Thank you so much.

CLAMAN: You got it.

Netflix prepares for earnings, but in these cell streaming device, it could be hurting its bottom-line.

At the end of the day, it is all about "money".

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: President Obama delaying his fundraising and campaign events today so that he can remain at the White House for a meeting with cabinet members on Ebola just moments ago.

White House Press Secretary John Earnest saying the president felt like he needed to be in the White House to fulfill his responsibilities. We're going to bring you any updates as we have them. That's a switch from the past by the way.

Netflix set to report a third-quarter earnings after the Belden stock came session lows after HBO announced it will launch a stand-alone streaming service for next year.

Our very own Jo Ling Kent is at the Nasdaq, James and Spencer back as well.

Jo, tell me about Netflix right now. What's it doing?

KENT: Well, it's down a little less than 1 percent. Now, like you said off the session lows, we're expecting an EPS of 93 cents of share, (inaudible) looking for a revenue of $1.41 billion. But there could be a silver lining here if HBO continues to be competitive to Netflix. Of all the people who are cutting quarters, maybe they'll migrate to Netflix as well.

FRANCIS: Yeah, interesting. Spencer, what do you think about Netflix after the bell and what do you think about the competition from HBO here?

ANTE: You know, honestly, I'm surprised that Netflix is not down more than 1 percent and change right now, you know, because HBO is saying they're going over the top is definitely the single biggest new competitor and threat they face when HBO releases that service in 2015.

So I think that people maybe underestimating the power of.

FRANCIS: OK.

ANTE: . this new service.

FRANCIS: James?

FREEMAN: Yeah, I think it suggests maybe questions about whether HBO can execute. As far as Netflix, obviously, they're priced for a lot of growth in the future. They have to pay a lot for programming, whether they can keep that edge in terms of user friendly experience.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

FREEMAN: Big question.

FRANCIS: OK. Thanks to all three of you. Stay tuned at Fox Business, we're going to have live coverage of Netflix earnings on "After the Bell" coming straight after this. That is all we have for now. I hope that you are somehow making money today. The market is down 279. It was much worse earlier. Stay tuned.

Liz Claman in "Countdown" starts right now.

END

urn:contentItem:5DCG-6751-DXH2-62GW-00000-00Fed Releases Beige Book; FED: Districts Generally Reporting Modest To Moderate Economic Growth; 10-Year Yield Hits 17-Month Low; Second Texas Health Care Worker Tests Positive For Ebola; Dallas Federal Reserve President Richard Fisher: Stock Market Plunge Does Not Mean the Economic Recovery has been Derailed; Walter Reed Begins Human Testing Of Ebola Vaccines; CDC Identifies Second Ebola Patient as Amber Vinson; Saudi Arabia's Prince Al Waleed bin Talal Slams Kingdom's Oil Policy2014-10-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:49:32ZLexisNexisMONEY2:00 PM ESTJames Freeman, Spencer Ante, Scott Shellady, Alan Knuckman, Dominic TavellaNEWSInternational101501cb.230Fed Releases Beige Book; FED: Districts Generally Reporting Modest To Moderate Economic Growth; 10-Year Yield Hits 17-Month Low; Second Texas Health Care Worker Tests Positive For Ebola; Dallas Federal Reserve President Richard Fisher: Stock Market Plunge Does Not Mean the Economic Recovery has been Derailed; Walter Reed Begins Human Testing Of Ebola Vaccines; CDC Identifies Second Ebola Patient as Amber Vinson; Saudi Arabia's Prince Al Waleed bin Talal Slams Kingdom's Oil PolicyMelissa Francis, Peter Barnes, Charlie Gasparino, Nicole Petallides, Jo Ling Kent, Tom Sullivan, David Asman, Richard Edson, Liz Claman

MELISSA FRANCIS, MONEY HOST: All three major averages down about 2.5 percent on the day. You could see there, the S&P, the biggest loser on a percentage basis.

Investors rushing to the safety of bonds, the 10-year treasury yield now at about 2 percent, just higher than that. It is the lowest level that we have seen since May of last year.

Now we are going to hear from the Fed. We are seconds away from the latest Beige Book report on the economy. We have an all-star panel standing by to react. There we go.

Let's go to Peter Barnes with the breaking news. Peter?

PETER BARNES, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Well, hi, Melissa, the 12 Federal Reserve banks reported modest to moderate economic growth in this latest survey of economic conditions. This is the Beige Book that the Fed will use at its next policy meeting at the end of this month when it is expected to end its latest round of quantitative easing.

I looked through the report to find -- check on some of the issues that are concerning investors right know exports, for example, to Europe and oil supplies and prices. And I did find this reference from the Cleveland Federal Reserve Bank. It said, "That manufacturing firms there seeing lower production attributed it to seasonal factors or declining exports."

On excess supplies of crude oil, the Beige Book does report on that and uses the term, "excess supplies" reporting on its context in the period up to October 6th. It says, "Oil exploration activity increased in the Minneapolis, Kansas City, and Dallas Districts." and of course the Minneapolis District does include those big shale oil reserves in North Dakota.

But, again, this information was all collected before October 6th. We've had a lot happened since then. The Dow down, 1,000 points since October 6th unclear how these latest developments in the markets will affect Fed policy making at the end of this month.

Melissa?

FRANCIS: All right, Peter Barnes reporting in disguise there. Thank you so much. Let's get to the market reaction right now.

It has been a rough run today. The Dow diving more than 400 points, so now we're down 420. When we came on the air a few seconds ago we were down 400. We're all over the map today. It is the steepest drop in more than three years. One of the big reasons, Ebola. Let's get you up to speed on the very latest on that one that caused the free fall this morning.

A second person contracted Ebola in the U.S. The patient has not yet been identified but it has been confirmed that the health care worker did travel by air before experiencing any symptoms of the deadly disease, the beginning of this week that was. The president is set to meet with cabinet leaders in just over an hour from now. They're going to discuss the government's response to this growing crisis.

Let's bring in today's panel. We have Fox Business's Charlie Gasparino, the Wall Street Journal's James Freeman is with us and co-founder of WhoWeUse, Spencer Ante is here as well.

Charlie?

CHARLIE GASPARINO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK: I would say part of the drop that's going down and every time we take eye an off the markets, it goes down.

FRANCIS: Right, it.

GASPARINO: And what do we have now, right?

FRANCIS: It's amazing. 420.

GASPARINO: To the point.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

GASPARINO: . I think some of the drop right now is attributed, I think, to David Asman's report earlier that Richard Fisher.

FRANCIS: Yes.

GASPARINO: . now he's a hawk but David reported exclusively that Fisher has ruled out QE. Look at it this way.

FRANCIS: Way too premature is what he said.

GASPARINO: . is that he's way too -- yes, way too -- so it means it's not going to happen anytime soon. Here is what the market loves. The market loves printing money. It knows that the global economy isn't doing so well. There's lots of fears out there. This is not a good environment to be owning stocks if the Fed is not going to ease.

FRANCIS: I think David Asman's going to be out later with more on that report. I just want to give you a couple of the headlines that are coming from David Asman's conversation with Fisher saying that the market correction doesn't mean the economy is in trouble. What do you think about that one, James Freeman?

JAMES FREEMAN, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL AND WHOWEUSE CO-FOUNDER: Well, I think that this is an issue we've talked about recently where he's trying to, I think, partly get out in front of his Fed colleagues. He knows a lot of them do not have market experience. And as academics, they can get rattled a bit.

FRANCIS: That's terrifying.

FREEMAN: . they can get rattled a bit sort of like Geithner was during the crisis where people on the street would whisper to him scary stuff without the experience to know he would kind of overreact. And I think that's what Fisher may be concerned about with some of his Fed colleagues.

GASPARINO: Do you think the economy is getting better? I mean.

FREEMAN: Slowly, yes, I do. And I think his point -- what Fisher, I think he's right on the money.

FRANCIS: You know, wait, wait, wait, I mean, let me stop you right there because you look at the data that's coming out of Germany, you look at the data that's coming out of China...

GASPARINO: Not good.

FRANCIS: . it seems like globally, I don't know, it feels like something has happened, something has shifted and we aren't all of a sudden getting better the way they were. You don't agree with that?

FREEMAN: I agree. Europe is depressing. I think the U.S. economy is still plugging along.

SPENCER ANTE, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: I agree with that. I think China is slowing down and Europ is slowing down but the U.S. is the main bright spot in the global economy. And.

FRANCIS: But how can we keep this lower.

GASPARINO: It's not going to last.

FRANCIS: Right. How can we keep this going.

GASPARINO: I will say this.

FRANCIS: . if they're staggering.

GASPARINO: Let's bring this politically.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

GASPARINO: One thing that Hillary Clinton is -- what she's worried about, big time, is the fact that economies generally -- economic cycles generally run in seven years. And seven year for this economic cycle is coming to an end.

FREEMAN: Yeah, but this isn't a normal cycle. It's been such slow growth.

GASPARINO: That is -- I know, that's the counter argument.

FREEMAN: Normally, I mean, it's different from so many other good.

FRANCIS: OK.

FREEMAN: . recoveries. So I wouldn't expect them.

GASPARINO: But we do know. But you don't know.

FREEMAN: . to be similar in that way.

FRANCIS: I want to -- Let's talk specifically about this big move that we've seen today because it is staggering.

Charlie, there were a lot of folks talking earlier today about maybe a Hedge Fund liquidation.

GASPARINO: Yeah, I mean, listen, here's the thing. You had that Shire deal, the Shire -- there was that.

FREEMAN: AbbVie.

GASPARINO: . AbbVie, right. Now that deal, this is a little technical, but here's what happened. A lot of people -- a lot of arbs got in that deal, meaning professional traders who bet the deal would happen. So they would go along the stock that was being bought. In short, the stock that was being sold, that was the acquirer.

FRANCIS: OK.

GASPARINO: . and guess what happened? That deal didn't happen. So all those arbs got crushed and what they did was they sold stock and they went into bonds. That's why you saw the 10-year go down on basis points and on the yield on 10-year go down.

My bigger point is this, deals like this generally screw up when the economy and the markets are insane.

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: Go ahead. Yeah, go ahead. Go ahead.

ANTE: And so obviously the bad news is outweighing good news in the market right now. But one bit of good news is that oil and gas prices are falling.

FRANCIS: No, no, that's not good news. That's not good news.

ANTE: No, that is good news. Let's not over think this.

FRANCIS: No, it's not.

ANTE: Let me finish my point.

FRANCIS: OK.

ANTE: Seventy percent of consumers spending in the U.S. economy -- of GDP comes your consumer spending. When oil prices and gas prices go down, it puts more people in money's pockets and they use.

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: That's a good side of it. The bad side of it is the reason why it's happening.

GASPARINO: Right.

FRANCIS: . it's because there is a global slowdown going down.

GASPARINO: Right.

FRANCIS: Look at what's happening.

ANTE: There's a global increase in supply of oil because of better technology.

GASPARINO: There's never any good -- there's never any

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: All of a sudden, out of nowhere? No. There's a shrinking of demand in China, in Europe and that's why.

ANTE: Supply is the big factor here.

GASPARINO: Let me ask you a question. Why is it then that every time we get a lousy print, GDP print, from overseas, price of oil goes down? I mean, it's totally.

FRANCIS: That's the precall that we've seen.

GASPARINO: Yes?

FREEMAN: But the result is a good one. Things get cheaper for all kinds of consumers.

FRANCIS: The result is a good one, but the question is which has the bigger impact? And I don't know.

(CROSSTALK)

ANTE: . but all these things that's horrible for the economy.

FRANCIS: Absolutely.

ANTE: Oil prices are going down. Let's not over think it. It's one of the only bright spots we have right now.

GASPARINO: But inflation goes down when your economy slows. You know that.

ANTE: We're not talking about inflation.

GASPARINO: I'm just saying.

ANTE: There's deflation.

FRANCIS: Let's get back to today's market right here. So what are you hearing from folks about this particular selloff right now down 424.

GASPARINO: A lot of.

FRANCIS: . does it continue? Is this the bottom? Is this the beginning?

GASPARINO: Who knows? I mean, yes, I think it continues until the Fed gives us some clarity on rates. whether they do a QE, whether Richard Fisher is obviously overruled. I would say this. When I talk to money managers that deal with high net worth people.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

GASPARINO: . but they're getting a lot of calls from their rich clients, they're asking about deflation. There is an issue, there's a little spook on deflation out in the market right now.

FRANCIS: What do you think about the 10-year? What's the 10-year telling you?

FREEMAN: Well, obviously there's a lot of fear and we've talked about fundamentals.

FRANCIS: Here it is right here.

FREEMAN: . you talk about Germany, you talk about Europe, not seeming to be sliding back into recession. U.S. consumer spending also is not good. But I think Ebola is also part of the fear factor today.

FRANCIS: Without question.

FREEMAN: Why shouldn't it be?

ANTE: I talked to a broker at JPMorgan, (Piven Kline) yesterday and they're actually advising their clients to buy into these dips. So that's just one major bank advising their wealthiest clients that, you know, that don't panic, you know, and that this is an opportunity over the long-term.

FRANCIS: Do you think it's an opportunity?

FREEMAN: I would discount the Ebola threat. I mean, definitely this is.

FRANCIS: You would or would not?

FREEMAN: I would. This is an economic catastrophe in those countries in Africa where tons of.

GASPARINO: Yeah, but here's why.

FRANCI: I think they're very easy to overreact to this.

GASPARINO: I suppose people, at least in a short-term for a quarter, stopped going to movie theaters, stopped flying.

FRANCIS: Right.

GASPARINO: I mean, there's going to be a sizable economic impact because of this. I'm not saying it's real. I'm not saying this is.

FRANCIS: I don't know. I don't know.

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: Are we away from that because they are talking about this, so now this second person that's contracted in the United States flew on Monday, they're talking about the 132 people that were on the plane with this person when they flew on Monday, tracking them down, who have they have been in contact with. She is now sick. I mean, it's.

GASPARINO: Melissa, a friend of mine went by the Dallas hub of Newark yesterday and it was empty. OK. I'm just telling you whether it's real, not real, whether we're overblown.

FRANCIS: OK.

GASPARINO: . it's having an impact.

FRANCIS: Really briefly though, I want to point out there is some green on the board. Shares of Time Warner climbing after CEO Jeff Bewkes announcing the company will more than double its earnings over the next several years. I mean, this is one of the stocks that's in the positive zone.

GASPARINO: Right.

FRANCIS: . that's been getting some attention today. I don't want to totally ignore it.

GASPARINO: Right.

ANTE: And also HBO announced it's going to be selling content.

GASPARINO: Right.

ANTE: . over the web for the first time ever. It's something that skeptics of Time Warner never thought they would ever do. I think that's a positive sign.

GASPARINO: I agree. And that story is bigger. That story -- if we didn't have the market going down this much would be the big headline.

ANTE: I agree.

GASPARINO: HBO going what's known as over the top is huge game-changer for the cable industry. They're basically saying we're going to bypass cable and we're going to be -- that puts more control.

ANTE: With the content owners.

GASPARINO: . with the content owners.

ANTE: Yeah.

GASPARINO: And here's the other thing. I think Jeff -- I think Bewkes. Whatever you said.

FRANCIS: Bewkes. Jeff Bewkes.

GASPARINO: I think he's a good CEO. Now, I know he turned down the Murdoch deal and, you know, our boss, Mr. Murdoch and he's going to be criticized for that because I don't think he'll be able to live up to his projections here. But low and behold, this guy is basically taking this company, he's squeezing it down and he's going to sell it to somebody.

FRANCIS: OK. We're going to pause for a second.

FREEMAN: But where is the growth?

FRANCIS: We have a market right now that's down 395 points. 60 days, that is how long the United Nation says we have to tackle Ebola before it becomes something uncontainable. Do you trust the government to handle it? We are going to be speaking to Dr. Ben Carson on what realistically can be done.

Plus, how Ebola made its way on to a flight with frontier airlines?

More "money," more answers. That's the big story. Coming up.

FRANCIS: Very steep declines across the board today in the market. The headlines are coming very fast.

The second Ebola identified. Lousy economic data weighing heavily. We just heard the latest from the Fed's Beige Book.

Let's go to Nicole Petallides on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. We also have Jo Ling Kent who is at the Nasdaq.

Nicole, let me start with you. Wild ride down there today.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: No doubt.

Melissa, what a wild ride this has been. You're talking about a thousand points that we've lost since last Wednesday's close.

Right now the Dow is down 380 points. We had been down 460 points, roughly a little less than that. And so you are seeing a broad-based selloff here. Everything is for sale. People are a little too nervous to take the risk. There's also some margin calls that maybe involved as well. But we are seeing some stocks that are shaving off some key numbers off the Dow Jones Industrial average.

So, three names, Goldman Sachs, Visa and Boeing actually accounting for about 100 points of the Dow's 375 points right now. So we can see Goldman down 3.7 percent, Visa down 2.6 percent and Boeing down 3.9 percent. It's also worth noting that Boeing itself is at a new low but big picture here, you're seeing all the major averages into negative territory for the year. The Dow, Nasdaq and the S&P, it's only the transports that's really heading on. The Russell also has been negative for this year. But transports had a tough October, don't forget, but still positive for the year.

So the selling is broad-based, energy, financials, health care weak. Yeah.

FRANCIS: OK, Jo, what are you seeing?

JO LING KEN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Well, we're looking at those big large caps, tech stocks of course here at the Nasdaq. They're all not doing terribly well here.

Take a look at Intel. Itself is down about 5 percent. It's shaving seven points off the Nasdaq composite right now. Vodafone also down quite a bit, one of the top losers of the hour here, Microsoft down as well as Expedia down 4 percent and of course apple down 2.6 percent, really dragging down some of these big tech stocks.

But although the Nasdaq overall right now is negative, the Nasdaq 100 continues to be positive just slightly for the year. So we're looking at all kinds of different global growth issues here. But Nasdaq 100 remains a silver lining for now.

FRANCIS: All right. Thank you so much. Thanks to both of you.

FRANCIS: President Obama delaying his fundraising and campaign events today so that he can remain at the White House for a meeting with cabinet members on Ebola just moments ago.

White House Press Secretary John Earnest saying the president felt like he needed to be in the White House to fulfill his responsibilities. We're going to bring you any updates as we have them. That's a switch from the past by the way.

Netflix set to report a third-quarter earnings after the Belden stock came session lows after HBO announced it will launch a stand-alone streaming service for next year.

Our very own Jo Ling Kent is at the Nasdaq, James and Spencer back as well.

Jo, tell me about Netflix right now. What's it doing?

KENT: Well, it's down a little less than 1 percent. Now, like you said off the session lows, we're expecting an EPS of 93 cents of share, (inaudible) looking for a revenue of $1.41 billion. But there could be a silver lining here if HBO continues to be competitive to Netflix. Of all the people who are cutting quarters, maybe they'll migrate to Netflix as well.

FRANCIS: Yeah, interesting. Spencer, what do you think about Netflix after the bell and what do you think about the competition from HBO here?

ANTE: You know, honestly, I'm surprised that Netflix is not down more than 1 percent and change right now, you know, because HBO is saying they're going over the top is definitely the single biggest new competitor and threat they face when HBO releases that service in 2015.

So I think that people maybe underestimating the power of.

FRANCIS: OK.

ANTE: . this new service.

FRANCIS: James?

FREEMAN: Yeah, I think it suggests maybe questions about whether HBO can execute. As far as Netflix, obviously, they're priced for a lot of growth in the future. They have to pay a lot for programming, whether they can keep that edge in terms of user friendly experience.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

FREEMAN: Big question.

FRANCIS: OK. Thanks to all three of you. Stay tuned at Fox Business, we're going to have live coverage of Netflix earnings on "After the Bell" coming straight after this. That is all we have for now. I hope that you are somehow making money today. The market is down 279. It was much worse earlier. Stay tuned.

Liz Claman in "Countdown" starts right now.

urn:contentItem:60PD-J4S1-JCNX-30XH-00000-00Fed's announcement will fuel stocks - but there's a warning for investors2020-08-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:49:32ZLexisNexisFed's announcement will fuel stocks - but there's a warning for investors

Link to Story

August 27, 2020 (Investorideas.com Newswire) The Fed's landmark monetary policy statement will trigger investors to pile further into equities - but beware of the lack of balance in the markets, warns the boss of one of the world's largest independent financial advisory organizations.The warning from Nigel Green, the CEO and founder of deVere Group, which has more than $12bn under advisement, comes after the U.S. Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell set out a major policy shift at the central bank's annual summit in Jackson Hole, Wyoming.Mr Green says: "The Fed chief has just outlined a highly-anticipated shake-up of the monetary policy of the world's de facto central bank."The Fed will keep interest rates at almost zero for the foreseeable future, possibly for more than five years, and it will take a more casual approach toward inflation, even championing a modest rise above their 2% target."He continues: "This will add fuel to global equities which are already on fire, having hit a record high on Wednesday."In this climate, holding bonds and sitting on cash will simply not provide the returns investors seek."Against this backdrop, many more will pile further into equities, which appear to be on a winning streak. But investors must beware of the lack of balance in the stock markets.

"A failure to recognise how unevenly distributed the gains are could prove to be a costly mistake."Not all stocks represent the same opportunities as others. Investors must bear this imbalance in mind."Indeed, the equities boom is driven by a handful of companies, mainly in Big Tech, which are accounting for a significant and disproportionate level of the capitalisation of stock indexes, including the benchmark S&P500 index."Therefore, buying an exchange-traded fund, or ETF, which are investment funds traded on stock exchanges, could, says the deVere CEO, expose investors unnecessarily.Nigel Green concludes: "The Fed's announcement could provide investors with lucrative rewards - but in these unusual times, serious and joined-up planning is required to take full advantage of the opportunities. Working with an experienced fund manager will best-position them to capitalize on these and also to mitigate potential risks of uneven markets."e:
t: +44 207 1220 925
Twitter: @PriorConsultsdeVere Group is one of the world's largest independent advisors of specialist global financial solutions to international, local mass affluent, and high-net-worth clients. It has a network of more than 70 offices across the world, over 80,000 clients and $12bn under advisement.
